info.game_comments: (Sofia: Pick up some defensive driving tips, today on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: Australia is home to the Torres Strait islanders & to the larger indigenous group usually called this

(2, 1).clue: As act one of this musical draws to a close, the lookout says, "Dear mother of God -- iceberg right ahead!"

(3, 1).clue: It's a payment on an insurance policy or a ranking, especially for a brand of saltine

(4, 1).clue: It's the Japanese art of tree dwarfing

(5, 1).clue: "Fowl" term for an abrupt withdrawal from the use of an addictive substance

(1, 2).clue: The Aleuts are the closest relatives of these people

(2, 2).clue: "The Capeman", this songwriter's musical about a killer, opened to protests, not to "Sounds of Silence"

(3, 2).clue: Insurers deal with this, the probability of loss; it's also the name of a Parker Brothers game

(4, 2).clue: The steenbok of Africa is a dwarf variety of this animal

(5, 2).clue: In 1947 Herbert Swope coined this 2-word phrase describing the political struggle between the U.S. & USSR

(6, 2).clue: It's the crisp, edible root of the plant Raphanus sativus, of the mustard family

(1, 3).clue: In 2001 Borneo's Dayaks were still engaged in this practice -- the bloody, not the corporate kind

(2, 3).clue: The Richard Rodgers musical "Rex" starred Nicol Williamson as this king who made some women lose their heads

(3, 3).clue: You're showing it if you're old enough to know it's the date a policy becomes payable

(4, 3).clue: Variations of these long-eared critters include the 28-pound Flemish giant & the 2-pound Netherland dwarf

(5, 3).clue: Cartoons featuring this mute penguin included "Snow Place Like Home" & "Polar Fright"

(6, 3).clue: I predict you'll know the name of this French astrologer who lived from 1503 to 1566

(1, 4).clue: The Havasupai were & are mainly based in what's now this U.S. state

(2, 4).clue: In a 1966 musical, Beauregard Jackson Pickett Burnside, husband of this title "Auntie", falls off an Alp

(3, 4).clue: Constitutions have amendments, wills have codicils, policies have these (like horses)

(4, 4).clue: A companion to the Dog Star Sirius, the Pup was the first star identified as one of these colorful objects

(5, 4).clue: The Weathermaker of 1928 was an air conditioner from this company adapted for home use

(6, 4).clue: It's the straight line extending from the center of a circle to the circumference

(1, 5).clue: Indigenous Hawaiians use this 5-letter word for non-indigenous Hawaiians

(2, 5).clue: The murder mystery musical "Something's Afoot" parodies the plot of this author's "Ten Little Indians"

(3, 5).clue: It's discrimination in issuing property insurance based on the property's location

(4, 5).clue: In Dickens' "Old Curiosity Shop", Quilp the dwarf has his evil eye on this "Little" character

(5, 5).clue: In Arctic or subarctic tundra, it's perennially frozen subsoil, also called pergelisol

(6, 5).clue: This electronics chain first opened in 1921 on Brattle Street, near the site of the Boston Massacre

(1, 1).clue: In 1804, 3 years after his son had been killed in a duel, this man was fatally shot on the same spot by Aaron Burr

(2, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the Las Vegas Motor Speedway.)  To keep the rubber on the road, racecar tires adapt an early U.S. slogan & say "Don't Put" this "on Me"

(3, 1).clue: The U.S. state known as the "Land of Shining Mountains" borders this country

(4, 1).clue: In the '70s governors of this state included Dale Bumpers & a future president

(5, 1).clue: Rats cut through an Inquisition prisoner's ropes, allowing him to escape this Poe title torture

(1, 2).clue: Button Gwinnett was killed in a duel over command of GA.'s military in May 1777, 10 months after signing this

(2, 2).clue: The day A.J. Foyt became the first 4-time winner of this race, Janet Guthrie became the first woman to drive in it

(3, 2).clue: This European grand duchy was founded in 963 when Count Siegfried acquired land in the area

(4, 2).clue: Dalia Messick became Dale to make it in the male-dominated comics world & created this female reporter

(5, 2).clue: (Hi-Ho, Kermit the Frog here!)  Published in 1865, this "Celebrated" story catapulted Mark Twain to fame
(5, 2).correct response: "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County"

(1, 3).clue: In 1806 this future president killed Charles Dickinson in a duel after Dickinson denounced him in the press

(2, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the Las Vegas Motor Speedway.)  Winston Cup stock car racing is named for a brand of this product, which I won't use when filling up

(3, 3).clue: The Czech Republic is bordered on the north by Poland, on the east by Slovakia & on the west by this country

(4, 3).clue: Dale Gardner made his first space flight on this shuttle in 1983; he quit the program after it exploded in 1986

(5, 3).clue: This James Thurber character envisions himself as the world's greatest pistol shot, among other things

(1, 4).clue: In 1598 this playwright & "To Celia" poet narrowly escaped the gallows for killing an actor in a duel

(2, 4).clue: Seating over 140,000, this state's Talladega Superspeedway claims the title of biggest motor sports facility

(3, 4).clue: The name of this most populous country in Africa contains the name of one of the countries it borders

(4, 4).clue: After you've won friends & influenced people next follow his advice on how to stop worrying & start living

(5, 4).clue: While in prison for embezzlement, he published his 1st short story, "Whistling Dick's Christmas Stocking"

(6, 4).correct response: What You See Is What You Get

(1, 5).clue: In 1829 Arthur Wellesley, who sported this title, challenged Lord Winchelsea to a duel; both missed their targets

(2, 5).clue: This other name for Grand Prix racing refers to the specifications of the Federation Internationale de L'Automobile

(3, 5).clue: With over 20 million, this country had more casualties during World War II than any other

(4, 5).clue: This minstrel tunes up in the tales of Robin Hood

(5, 5).clue: His 1921 collection "The Trembling of a Leaf" contained "Miss Thompson", which was later dramatized as "Rain"

(0, 0).clue: The 1979 sequel to this miniseries is set in Henning, Tennessee, beginning in 1882
